climbs.name: Bagtown
climbs.fa: Max Fisher, Marty Theriault, Luc Gallant

content.description:
Cool line that meanders up a gully just right of Chasing the Sun. Thin ice makes this an R route for pro. 

Located high on the east wall next to Chasing the Sun. Walk up past NB Pillar and look for a gully that goes up and right. 
A rack of screws. Rap the route.

Make a few spicy but relatively easy moves on rock to gain the ice, climb it to the top.



Starts in a small gully right of Jaundice. Head up to a ledge and traverse left to join the ice.

Bring some small gear and ice screws

The brother of Simple Forgotten. Very similar climbing but slightly better protection and some mixed if it is not fat. Start up the narrow ramp just right of SF.
Pitch 1 - Sustained steep climbing for about 35 meters then step up and right to a ledge. Belay here off bolts if you want to do it in two pitches or if the crux pitch is not in condition.
Pitch 2 - Move up and left off the belay ledge. Clip a bolt then move through the rock section before transitioning left back onto the ice (crux). Continue up a short vertical section of ice then slightly less steep to the top. Belay on a large ledge at another bolted anchor. 20 meters.

Located high on the east wall on left hand side, between Simply Forgotten and Bagtown. 
A full rack of screws including stubbies. Rap the route.

Sustained steep climbing for 45 ish meters. The climb usually forms some very cool mushrooms and cauliflowers. Can be done in 2 pitches or one long one. 

On the east wall, up and right of the main waterfall coming off the river (Missing Amigo). Jaundice is the slightly easier line to the right on the largest flow. 
A full rack of screws. Tree anchor.

climbs.name: The Missing Amigo
climbs.fa: A. Parsons and J. Parsons February, 1994

content.description:
This is the main waterfall that you will see when looking north upriver. There are a number of routes on it ranging from WI2 to probably WI4 depending on the time of year you are there. If there has been a lot of snow it will be difficult to get an anchor in anywhere but on the right hand side of the flow where you will find a tree.

On the river. Main waterfall. 
A rack of screws.

climbs.name: Mooring Lines
climbs.fa: Matthew Peck, Kristen & Leanne Fisher Jan 28, 2014

content.description:
A long, winding ramp above the small fall encountered in the crag description.  The remains of an old dam at the base inspired the name.  This was a consolation prize for an epic day of cross country route finding in deep snow, the river was out above and it was too late in the day to continue.  This route forks above for a second pitch and this route follows the left side. 



Approach the crag via the river, and look left at the small fall. 

Standard ice Rack.

climbs.name: New Brunswick Pillar
climbs.fa: Marty Theriault, Luc Gallant and Max Fisher

content.description:
This is the jewel in the Moose River crown. Splendid climbing on a dead vertical pillar of awesomeness. 
History: For some very odd reason this route was unclimbed until 2013 when three New Brunswick hardmen strolled in to see what Moose River was all about. They were shocked to see such a great area with such potential. They wasted no time dispatching this gem. 

Pretty hard to miss. This is the obvious steep pillar just left of Jaundice. 
A full rack of screws. Rap the route.

climbs.name: Simply Forgotten
climbs.fa: Max Fisher and Luc Gallant, December 2014

content.description:
Beautiful narrow line of ice weaving it's way to the top of the wall. Sections of very sustained, steep climbing on often thin, delaminated ice. Mental and technical test piece and exercise in delicate footwork. Would climb best in late January early February. It will likely be difficult to get pro in for the final 30 feet or so.

Located high on the left side of the east wall. Look for a narrow line of ice furthest left. 
A full rack of screws, especially shorter ones.

A cool line!  Climb the overhanging choss (hopefully its cold, as this is loose and unprotect able) to a ledge, and then up a short pillar to the belay above. A neat looking feature but maybe not worth the risk. The FA was aborted before the final Topout due to poor ice conditions and a rap was made from the base of the pillar. 



Just upriver of the small fall on the East bank. 

Pins, and Thin ice pro.

Beautiful spot to spend a day climbing ice ranging from short and easy to long and hard. Faces south/southwest so you get sun from late morning till dusk. About a dozen or so routes will keep you busy. Lots of hard mixed potential for someone looking to develop.
